svg.content: <mxfile host="Electron" modified="2020-03-28T14:02:39.521Z" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_12_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) draw.io/12.6.5 Chrome/80.0.3987.86 Electron/8.0.0 Safari/537.36" etag="BPDdBOgkXk5q6NCndZN-" version="12.6.5" type="device"><diagram id="LwdlgLjF_MohSxHoXpEQ" name="Page-1"></diagram></mxfile>

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 248px; height: 1px; padding-top: 84px; margin-left: 48px;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Implication Shapes
The implication of a pattern can be as simple as an obvious extension or repetition of the pattern, like an hypothesized additional vector in the same direction & of the same magnitude, appended in the same way, as a chain of vectors (right).
An implication can also be a similarity, such as when vectors going in the same direction are implied to be similar.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 301px; height: 1px; padding-top: 634px; margin-left: 22px;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The implication can be more complicated than pattern extension or similarity; in the case of the shape with three connected sides, you have an implied fourth side which is also a:
- connection
- completion of a closed shape
Not just a repetition of a pattern (rotate 90 degrees & connect at endpoints).
The implication relies on the concept of a closed shape in order to infer the fourth side as the logical next step, unless you use the pattern repetition to close the shape, and identify the concept of a closed shape after closing the shape through pattern repetition.
The implications of a closed shape have different information traces like input/emergent intents - if the intent of the pattern is to create a closed shape, then the shape will close if you let the pattern continue uninterrupted.
The shape may diverge from the obvious pattern: it may be a pattern that strictly only executes the steps if it's not going to form a closed shape, and if it is about to, it changes its steps (repeat rotation at 90 degrees until it doesn't create a closed shape) to ensure that it doesn't create a closed shape. This is slightly less obvious than the original implication of the pattern, which is the closed square shape, but it could be equally valid or even likelier, depending on the system incentives or intents.

switch.text: The implication can be more complicated than patte...
